title: How to Give Humira Injections

steps.headline: Wash and dry your hands.
steps.description: Place your hands under cold running water to wet them. Squeeze a small amount of soap in the palm of your hand. Rub your hands together for 20 seconds until a thick lather forms. Place your hands under the running water to rinse them until all of the soap is removed. Turn off the faucet and dry your hands with a clean paper towel.

steps.headline: Gather your materials.
steps.description: Remove the Humira pen from your refrigerator. It is a prefilled syringe with the needle already in place. Place the pen, a cotton ball or gauze, and an alcohol swab on a flat surface like a tray, counter, or table. Retrieve your sharps container as well. Check the medication's expiration date as well. If it has expired, do not use it and contact your pharmacy. If you would like the medication to be room temperature at the time of the injection, remove the pen from the refrigerator 30 minutes before you plan to use it.

steps.headline: Sit in a comfortable position.
steps.description: The couch or an armchair are both suitable. However, make sure that the area where you are sitting is well lit. This way you can inspect the medication and the injection site thoroughly before you inject the medicine.

steps.headline: Make sure the medication is filled.
steps.description: The pen contains a small window, which enables you to see the medication. Holding the pen with the grey cap pointing down, check to see that the liquid is up to the fill line. If it isn't, do not use the pen and call your pharmacy. The pen has 2 caps: a grey cap and a plum-colored cap. The grey cap has the number 1 on it and the plum-colored cap has the number 2 on it.

steps.headline: Inspect the medication for cloudiness, discoloration, and particles.
steps.description: Flip the pen so that the grey cap is pointing up. Check to see that the liquid is clear. If you see a few bubbles, that is ok. However, if the liquid is discolored, is cloudy, or contains particles or flakes, do not use it. Call your pharmacy, as the medication may be contaminated.

steps.headline: Choose an injection site.
steps.description: You can either choose the top of your thigh or the lower part of your stomach. If you choose your lower stomach area, make sure the injection site is 2 inches (5.1 cm) away from any side of your belly button. Choose a site that is free of bruises, sores, lesions, scars, scaly patches, or stretch marks. An injection in the outer part of your thigh or your lower stomach will hurt the least, due the muscle and fat in those areas.

steps.headline: Clean the injection site with alcohol for 20 seconds.
steps.description: Rub the injection site with the alcohol swab for 20 seconds. Let the injection site dry completely before proceeding, about 10 to 15 seconds. If you do not have an alcohol swab, use a cotton ball dipped in 70 to 90% isopropyl alcohol instead.

steps.headline: Remove the pen's caps.
steps.description: Use 1 hand to hold the middle of the pen, in between the 2 caps, with the grey cap pointing up. Use your other hand to pull the grey cap straight off. The grey side contains the needle. Set the grey cap aside. Then pull the plum cap straight off. The plum side contains the injection button. Set the plum cap aside. Flip the pen so that the needle is pointing down. Do not touch the needle, and avoid placing the caps back on the pen. If a little bit of liquid comes out of the needle when you pull the grey cap off, that is ok.

steps.headline: Squeeze the injection site with 1 hand.
steps.description: Use your finger and thumb to gently squeeze or stretch the area of skin, about 1 inch (2.5 cm) in length, where the injection site is. The needle is quite small, so you don't need to squeeze too tightly. If you are giving the injection to someone besides yourself, ask if you are squeezing their skin too hard. They should not feel any pain.

steps.headline: Place the white end of the pen directly on the injection site.
steps.description: Hold the pen flat against the injection site. Make sure to hold the pen at a 90-degree angle relative to your skin. If you are giving someone else the injection, tell them to take a deep breath to relax. Let them know you are going to count to 3 and give the injection on the count of 3.

steps.headline: Release the medication.
steps.description: Use your thumb to press the plum-colored button. Once the button engages, you will hear a loud click. Once you hear the click, keep pressing the button for 10 seconds, or until you see the yellow marker in the window stop moving. Once all of the medication is injected, pull the pen straight up and away from your skin. When giving the injection to someone else, ask them if they are ready. When they say, “Yes,” begin counting and give the injection on the count of 3.

steps.headline: Clean your hands.
steps.description: Turn on the faucet and place your hands under the cold running water. Place a small amount of soap in your hand. Rub your hands together until a thick lather forms, about 20 seconds. Rinse your hands until all of the soap is removed. Turn off the faucet and dry your hands with a clean paper towel.

steps.headline: Place your materials on a flat surface.
steps.description: Remove the Humira syringe from your refrigerator. Place the syringe, an alcohol swab, and a cotton ball on a flat surface like a table or tray. Check your medication's expiration date to see if it has expired. Grab your sharps container as well. If the medication has expired, do not use it and contact your pharmacy. If a nurse is coming to give the injection, remove the syringe from the refrigerator 30 minutes before the application. You could use a plastic milk jug for a sharps container, if necessary.

steps.headline: Sit in a comfortable, well-lit area in your house.
steps.description: The couch, a kitchen table chair, or an armchair are all suitable places to sit. However, make sure where you are sitting is well lit. This way you can inspect the syringe and the injection site thoroughly before you dispense the medicine.

steps.headline: Check to see that the medication is clear.
steps.description: Shake the syringe, then hold it with the needle pointing down and inspect the liquid. The liquid should be colorless and clear. If the liquid is discolored, cloudy, or contains flakes or particles, do not use it. Choose a different syringe from your refrigerator instead and call your pharmacy to tell them the medication may be contaminated.

steps.headline: Choose the top of your thigh or lower stomach for the injection site.
steps.description: If you choose your lower stomach area, make sure the injection site is 2 inches (5.1 cm) away from any side of your belly button. Additionally, do not choose a site that has sores, lesions, scaly patches, bruises, thick skin, scars, or stretch marks. Giving an injection in the fatty, outer part of your thigh will hurt less and is easy to access.

steps.headline: Clean the injection site.
steps.description: Rub the injection site with the alcohol swab for 20 seconds. Let the injection site dry completely before injecting the medication, about 10 to 15 seconds. If you are giving someone else the injection, sit in a chair in front of them. Use a cotton ball dipped in 70 to 90% isopropyl alcohol if you do not have an alcohol swab.

steps.headline: Check that the dosage is correct.
steps.description: Hold the body of the syringe with your finger and thumb, like a pencil. The needle should be pointing down and the plunger pointing up. Check how full the syringe is. The dosage in the syringe should match the dosage prescribed by your doctor. If the dosage is incorrect, do not use the medication and call your pharmacist.

steps.headline: Remove the air from the syringe by pushing the plunger.
steps.description: Remove the needle's cover and set it aside. Turn the syringe so that the needle is pointing up. As you do this, you should see a bubble rise to the top. Use your other hand to push the plunger. Slowly push the plunger until you see 1 to 2 drops of liquid come out of the needle.

steps.headline: Hold the syringe at a 45-degree angle.
steps.description: Find the hole in the needle of the syringe. Turn the syringe so that hole in the needle the needle is facing down. Use your thumb and finger to hold the syringe's body like a pencil at a 45-degree angle. If you are giving someone else the injection, tell them to take a deep breath to relax. Let them know you are going to count to 3 and give the injection on the count of 3.

steps.headline: Insert the needle into your skin.
steps.description: Use the finger and thumb of your free hand to squeeze skin, about 1 inch (2.5 cm) in length, around the injection site. Using a quick, smooth motion, insert the needle into the injection site at a 45-degree angle. Once the needle is inserted, let go of your skin. Then gently pull the plunger back with your free hand. If you are giving someone else the injection, do so on the count of 3. It is not unusual to see blood during the injection. If you see blood in the plunger, this means you entered a blood vessel. Stop pulling the plunger and slowly remove the needle at a 45-degree angle. Place it in the sharps container and use a new syringe.

steps.headline: Inject the medicine.
steps.description: Slowly push the plunger until all of the medicine is injected, or the syringe is empty. Remove the needle from your skin at a 45-degree angle once all of the medication is injected.

steps.headline: Throw the pen or syringe away in a sharps container.
steps.description: Do this immediately after you remove the needle. Avoid throwing the syringe away in the trash. Place the sharps container up high and away from children and pets. If you are using a homemade sharps container, like a milk jug, tape it closed and put it directly in the trash.

steps.headline: Hold the cotton ball against the injection site for 10 seconds.
steps.description: It is alright if there is a small amount of blood or fluid at the injection site. Place the cotton ball or gauze against the injection site and hold it there for 10 seconds. Contact your pharmacist if there is too much bleeding, or if the bleeding will not stop after you remove the pen or syringe.

steps.headline: Make a note of when and where you injected the medication.
steps.description: In a notebook, write down the date and time of the injection. Also write down exactly where you injected the medication. For your next injection, choose a site that is at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) away from the last injection site. Alternate between your stomach and thigh for injection sites. After 2 weeks, you can reuse an injection site.

Place your hands under cold running water to wet them.
Squeeze a small amount of soap in the palm of your hand.
Rub your hands together for 20 seconds until a thick lather forms.
Place your hands under the running water to rinse them until all of the soap is removed.
Turn off the faucet and dry your hands with a clean paper towel.
Gather your materials.
Remove the Humira pen from your refrigerator.
It is a prefilled syringe with the needle already in place.
Place the pen, a cotton ball or gauze, and an alcohol swab on a flat surface like a tray, counter, or table.
Retrieve your sharps container as well.
Check the medication's expiration date as well.
If it has expired, do not use it and contact your pharmacy.
If you would like the medication to be room temperature at the time of the injection, remove the pen from the refrigerator 30 minutes before you plan to use it.
Sit in a comfortable position.
The couch or an armchair are both suitable.
However, make sure that the area where you are sitting is well lit.
This way you can inspect the medication and the injection site thoroughly before you inject the medicine.
Make sure the medication is filled.
The pen contains a small window, which enables you to see the medication.

If it isn't, do not use the pen and call your pharmacy.

Check to see that the liquid is clear.
If you see a few bubbles, that is ok.
However, if the liquid is discolored, is cloudy, or contains particles or flakes, do not use it.
Call your pharmacy, as the medication may be contaminated.
Choose an injection site.
You can either choose the top of your thigh or the lower part of your stomach.
If you choose your lower stomach area, make sure the injection site is 2 inches (5.1 cm) away from any side of your belly button.
Choose a site that is free of bruises, sores, lesions, scars, scaly patches, or stretch marks.
An injection in the outer part of your thigh or your lower stomach will hurt the least, due the muscle and fat in those areas.

The grey side contains the needle.
Set the grey cap aside.
Then pull the plum cap straight off.
The plum side contains the injection button.

Do not touch the needle, and avoid placing the caps back on the pen.
If a little bit of liquid comes out of the needle when you pull the grey cap off, that is ok.
Squeeze the injection site with 1 hand.

The needle is quite small, so you don't need to squeeze too tightly.
If you are giving the injection to someone besides yourself, ask if you are squeezing their skin too hard.
They should not feel any pain.

Make sure to hold the pen at a 90-degree angle relative to your skin.
If you are giving someone else the injection, tell them to take a deep breath to relax.
Let them know you are going to count to 3 and give the injection on the count of 3.
Release the medication.
Use your thumb to press the plum-colored button.
Once the button engages, you will hear a loud click.
Once you hear the click, keep pressing the button for 10 seconds, or until you see the yellow marker in the window stop moving.
Once all of the medication is injected, pull the pen straight up and away from your skin.
When giving the injection to someone else, ask them if they are ready.
When they say, “Yes,” begin counting and give the injection on the count of 3.
